abstract.p: Grace Glueck reviews exhibition of works by Brian Kenny at DC Moore Gallery (S)

block.p: D. C. Moore Gallery 724 Fifth Avenue, near 57th Street Manhattan Through next Friday

Any artist who arranges objects within small, elegant, glass-fronted wooden boxes cannot escape the long shadow of Joseph Cornell, and Brian Kenny is no exception. His carefully made containers, resembling 19th-century clock cases and other period furniture forms, are often quaintly lined with printed papers in French and other languages, tastefully inflected by a pasted postage stamp or two. They contain assortments of sometimes distasteful things, like cicada carcasses, along with bone fragments, wine glasses (broken and whole), old shoe trees, antlers and wishbones.

''The Overall Swellness of Mrs. O'Grady'' presents a clear glass vase partly filled with cicada shells and a large oak leaf against a background of printed paper. ''Thoreau to Masefield'' is set up as a wine glass on a gilded pedestal, supported by a bony structure that looks like the skull of an animal, backed by a printed paper.
D. C. Moore Gallery 724 Fifth Avenue, near 57th Street Manhattan Through next Friday

Any artist who arranges objects within small, elegant, glass-fronted wooden boxes cannot escape the long shadow of Joseph Cornell, and Brian Kenny is no exception. His carefully made containers, resembling 19th-century clock cases and other period furniture forms, are often quaintly lined with printed papers in French and other languages, tastefully inflected by a pasted postage stamp or two. They contain assortments of sometimes distasteful things, like cicada carcasses, along with bone fragments, wine glasses (broken and whole), old shoe trees, antlers and wishbones.

''The Overall Swellness of Mrs. O'Grady'' presents a clear glass vase partly filled with cicada shells and a large oak leaf against a background of printed paper. ''Thoreau to Masefield'' is set up as a wine glass on a gilded pedestal, supported by a bony structure that looks like the skull of an animal, backed by a printed paper.
For comic relief, there is ''All of Those Damned Thanksgivings,'' a case packed artfully with turkey wishbones.
Innovative this show is not, but the contrast between the elegance of the cases and their content saves it from being too precious.
